O minério cle fctro e os itabiritos cla Mina de Águas Claras foram estuclados em detalhe
do ponlo de vista mineralógico, petrológico e geoquímico, com os objetivos de caracterizá-los e
cle contribuir pala o melhor entendimento da gênese dos mesmos. Dois tipos de itabiritos ocorrem em Águas Claras: dolomítico e qnartzo itabilito, Os minérios cle alto teor (%F e >64%)
foram fo¡mados a partir clo primeiro. Tanto um como outro tipo de itabirito apresentam meso e
microbandamento. No itabirito clolomítico alternam-se bandas ricas em hematita com balrclas
ricas etn dolomita, enquanto quc no quartzo itabirito a alternânoia ocotle entre bandas ricas ern
quartzo com banclas ricas em hematita. Dolomita, qualtzo e hematita são os princìpais constituintes tnineralógicos, ocorrendo clo|rta, sericita, talco e apatita como mûrerais acessórios.
A composição química dos itabiritos é rnuito simples. Fe:O¡, CaO, MgO e PF são os principais
componentes clo itabirito dolomítico e Fe2O3 e SiO2 do quartzo itabirito. Os teol'es de elementos
menores são geralmente inferiores a l0 ppm, talìto no itabirito dolomítico como no quartzo itabirito, sem evidenciarem uma maior concentração em um ou outro tipo de BIF. Apenas Zn, Sr
e Pb estão mais caracteristicamente associados com o itabirito dolomítico, e Cd, Sb e Ge com o
quartzo itabirito. O padrão de fracionamento dos ETR, quando normalizados pelo padrão PAAS,
assemelha-se aos de outras BIFs paleoproterozóicas, com auomalias positivas de Eu e Y e âumento gradativo dos ETR leves em direção aos pesados. Os isótopos de C e O do itabirito

As Minas de Águas Claras e Pico são cluas minas cle ferro cle classe munclial, hospedaclas

A gêtrese do minério friável cle alto teor e clo itabirito rico clas Minas cle Águas Claras e

A Forrnação Cauê, do Supergrupo Minas, é composta por formações ferríferas bancladas (BlFs) paleoproterozóicas clo tipo "Lago Superior", denominaclas regionalmente de itabiritos.

Este tópico é apresentado sob a forma do artigo "The high-grade iron ores of the Aguas
Claras mine, Quadrilátero Ferrífero, Brazil" (Spier, C.A; Oliveira, S.M.B.; Rosière, C.A; Ardisson, J.D. 2005. Mineralium Deposita - submeti<lo), no Anexo 3. O artigo trata do tema cenhal da tese, qìre é a caracterizaçio e a gênese do minério cle fero cla Mina de Águas Claras.
São apresentados datlos minemlógicos, petrológicos e geoquhnicos pa(a os minérios friável e

minérios, é feita uma rápida apresentação cla geologia dos Depósitos cle Capão Xavier e Tamanduá, de modo a melhor ilustrar a complexidade dos processos que levaram a for.mação clos
vários tipos cle minério de l'erro no Quadrilátero Fenífero. Apresenta-se, a seguir, uma síntese do
artigo.
Muitos depósitos de feno de classe mundial ocofl:etn no Quadrilátero Ferífero, na região
sucleste do Brasil, oncle formagões ferríferas bandatlas metamorfisadas e heterogeneamente
deformadas, regionalmente clenominadas de itabiritos, foram convertidas em minérios hematíticos de alto (Fe>64%) e baixo (30%<Fe<64%) teor de ferro. Com base em sua composigão mineralógica, são clescritos três tipos principais cle jtabiritos no Quadrilátero Fenífero: qr.rartzo itabirito, itabirito dololîítico e itabirito anfibolítico. Diferentemente cle outras
miuas no Quailrilátero Ferrífero, oncle os miné¡ios de alto teor oconem associaclos a minérios de
baixo teor, na Mina cle Águas Claras os minérios de alto teor são largarnente pleclominantes,
tendo sido formados a partir do itabirito dolomítico. Dois ripos principais cle minério de alto teor

dolomítico (protominério), particularmente o meso e microbandamento, característica esta refletida nas bandas maciças e porosas rlo minério. O minério compacto é muito denso e duro.
Ele ocorre como lenles métricas a decimétricas, isoladas, tanto no meio do minérìo fiiável como
no interior clo itabirito dolomítico inalterado. Os rninérios fiiável e compacto são formados
essencialmente por hematita, a qual ocone na forma cle martita, hematitâ anédrica, granular e

tabttlar e, localmeute, especular. Os minerais de ganga são muito raros, consistinclo de cÌolomita,

As análises químicas mosffaram que os minérios hiável e compacto consistem quas€ que totalmente de FezO:, com maiores quantidades de impurezas, especialmente MnO, no minério
friável. Tanto o minério friável como o minério oompacto são extremamente pobres em elementos traços.
Os minérios c1e alto teor da Milla de Águas Claras tem origens distintas, envolvendo processos hipogênicos e supergênicos. A ocorência do rniuério compacto no interior do itabirito
dolomítico inalterado é uma boa indicação de sua origem hipogênica. Apesar dos questionamentos em relação qênese do itabirito dolomítico (se esta rocha representa uma fäcics carbonática da Formação Cauê ou se resulta da substituição hidrotennal do chert/quarlzo por
dolomita), cliversas características obselaclas no minério friável inclicam a sua origern supergênica, comor por exemplo: (l) a transição lateral e vertical para o itabirito ctolomítico, (2) o gradual desaparecimento em proftrndidacle, formanclo interdigitações com estâ rocha, (3) a presença em meio ao minério cle blocos isolados do pl'otominério, em tudo similares ao itabirito
dolomítico que ocorre fora cla área mineralizada, (4) a presença de dobras d,o trpo kink e slump,
ausentes no protominério, as quais em conjunto com a ocouência de clepressões preenchiclas por
sedimentos te¡ciários recobrindo parcialmente o corpo de rninério, inclicam o colapso do mesmo
após a lixiviação t1a dolomita, (5) a presença de feuihidrita e cle minerais de manganôs fonnados
a paltir da clissolução da clolomita, (6) padrões de fracionamento dos ETR idênticos aos do itabirito dolomítico.
A composição mineralógica dos itabiritos teve um papel importante na gônese dos minérios de alto e baixo teor no Quadrilátero Ferrífelo. A comparação entre a geologia cla Mina de Águas Claras com a cle Capão Xaviel e Tamancluá, mostrou que, sob idênticas condições
estruturais, topográfìcas e climáticas, o itabirito dolomítico é muito mais favo¡ável dormação cle
depósitos de f'erro de alto teor do que o quartzo itabirito. Forneceu tarnbém irrclicações<le qne a
gênese de depósitos friáveis cle alto teor a partir do quartzo itabirito requer a atuação de outros
controles além do litológico, possivelmente envolvendo processos hipogênicos e supergênicos,

The geology ancl lithostratigraphy of the Quadrilátero Ferrífero wore described in det¿il
by the USGS-DNPM team between 1946 and 1963, ancl summarized by Dorr (1969). Since then,
the subject has been leviewed by several authors (Ladeira and Viveitos 1984, Marshak and
Alkmim 1989, Chemale Jr. et al. 1994, Renger et al. 1994, Alkrnrm and Marshak 1998). The
most important lithostratigraphic units of the Quaclrilátero Ferrífero (Figs. I anct 3) are the Archean to Paleoproterozoic granite-gueiss terrains, the Archean greenstone belt sequences (Rio
clas Velhas Supergroup), the Minas Supergroup and the post-Minas intrusive rocks.
The giant iron ore deposits of the Quadrilátero Ferrífero are hosted in the rnetamorphosed
sedimentary rocks of lhe Minas Supergroup, which consists of three Paleoproterozoic sequences
(Renger et al. 1994; Noce 1995; Babinsky et al. 1995). The lowest unit is the Caraça Group,
which consists of alluvial conglomerate and sandstone grading upwards into shallow-watsr
marine pelites. The micldle ltabira Group consists mainly of chemical sedimentary rocks. An
extensive iron formation layer with variable composition occurs at the base of the Itabira Group
and, together with hematitic ancl clolomitic phyllites, marbles ancl dolomites, comprises the Cauê
Formation. The sequence grades upward to dolomites and ilolomitic/manganiferous itabirites of
the 2.4 Ga Gandarela Formation (Babinsky et al. 1995). Clastic sediments (with subordinate
dolomites) of the Piracicaba Group occur over the Itabira Gror.rp. The uppermost sequence of the
Minas Supergroup is the Sabará Group, a sequence of metamotphosed volcanoclastics, tulbidites, banclecl iron- formations (BIFs) and conglomerates, considered to belong to the
Transamazonian orogenic periocl (2.1 - 1.7 Ga., Renger et al. 1994). Post-Minas intlusives, namely grânite, pegmatite, metamorphosed mafic dykes and
cliabase, cr.rt the Rio das Velhas and Minas Supergroups. Granitc and pegmatito cutting basement
rocks yield monazite and zircon U-Pb ages of 2,06 and 2.08 Ga respectively Q.ioce 1995).
Foliatecl and metamorphosed mafic clykes occur throughout the Quadrilátero Feuífelo. One of
thenr yielded a 1.714 Ga age (Alkmim ancl Marshak 1998). Diabase ancl gabbros, not affecte<l by
metamorphism, are also encountered locally (Pomenere 1964, Wallace 1965).
A supergene cap locally called canga covers the iron ores and other rocks in the Quadrilátero Fenífero. It consists of a lithified superfìcial or near-sutface iron-rich rock formed
with various quantities of detrital fragments, commonly iron ores or itabirites, cemented by
limonite into a blanketing body (Dorr 1964).

The Itabirites of the ltabira Group
Itabirites are oxidized, metamorphosed ancl heterogeneously deformecl banded iron
formations (BIFs) containing discontinuously ilistributed orebo<ìies, which vary in scale from just a few centimeters to hundrecls of meters. Multipte processes have obliteraled partially or
totally the mineralogy, texture and structure of the original secliments, making it difficult to identify primary characteristics, especially in the high-strain domain. In the lo.,,v strain domâirì,
the itabirites have preserved several sedimentary and diagenetic features snch as meso and
microbanding pocls formed by clifferential compaction and pisolites (Rosiere ct al. 2001). Banding is the main intemal feature of the itabirites. Tight ancl isoclinal folds commonly showing a crenulation cleavage and pinch-ancl-swell structures are locally observed. Shear zones
ate restrictecl to a few places and founcl parallel to banding or truncating it. Kink-bands are very

collapse structures.
Quartz itabirite is the major type of itabirite in the Quaclrilátero Ferrífero. In this rock
type the original chert or jasper bands l'rave been recrystallizecl into granular quartz, and iron ìs
present as hematite, magnetite or martite. Dolomitic itabirite is a dolomitized BIF consisting of
alterna[ing recl carbonate and black iron oxide bands, eacl, being between I mm and 50 crn thick.
Arnphibolitic itabirite consists of bancls of many types of amphiboles (grunerite, tremolite, actinolite, cummingtonite ancl/or anthophilite) alternating with bancls of iron oxicles (Rosière et
al. 1993).
llematite is the major iron oxicle in dìe itabirites, occuring in clifferent forms: martite
(pseuclomorphs of hematitc af'ter magne tite), granular hematite and specularite (Don 1964, 1965;
Rosière 1981, 1983, 2000). Magnetite appears subordinately as the Fe2r. deficient variety
kenomagnetite (metastable magnetic phases which are somewhere between magnetite and
maghemite in composition), and as relicts in martite ancl hematite aggregates. Both iron oxicles
were developecl at various stages during the complex evolution of the Quadrilátero Ferrífero, as
shown by Rosière (,l981, 1983) and Rosière et al, (2001). Magnetite is the oldest recognizable
iron oxide. Mostly it appears to have been totally or partially martitized. Granular hematite results from the progressive martitization, inversion and recrystallization of magnetite. Specularite results from recrystallization of kenomagnetite, martite or hernatite in high-strain
domains or shear zones (Rosière et al. 2001). Otherwise it occurs in extensional sites associated

Quartz is the main gangue mineral of itabirites. The next most common are dolomite ancl
amphiboles, which are present either as intelcalated bands ot disseminations. Chlorite, talc, apatite and various silicate minerals occur in very smâll quantities except in the high metamorphic-grade zones, where they can be common (Dorr 19'13). Genetic Models For Thc lron Ores
Although largely discussed in the intcmational literatrro, the genesis of the high-gracle
iron ore deposits hostecl within BIFs remains unclear. Different genetic models have been proposed worldwide to explain the iron enrichment of the BIFs. Morris (2002) identified eleven
iron ole gerretic moclels and groupecl them in three classes: syngenetic, supergene and hypogene.
Based on field investigations and literature surveys, Beukes et al. (2002) recognized three genetic models of high-grade iron ore deposits: ancient supergener hydrothermal ancl supergene-
modifi eil hydrothermal deposits.
The supergene models explain the iron enrichment as a tesult of leaching of the gangue
minerals by supergene fluids. (e.g. Dor 1964, Monis 1985). These models are generally accepted as an explanation for the high-grade iton ores associated with present or past erosion
surfaces. Hypogene models are more complex. They propose the action of hydrothermal fluids
substituting tlre gangue minerals for iron oxides o¡ iron carbonates (e.g. Dorr 1965, Gruner 1937,
Powell et ù1. 1999, Morey 1999). Taylor et al. (2001) recently proposed a composite model to
explain the genesis of the high-grade iron ore of the llamersley Province. For a general understanding concerning the high-grade iron ores genesis see Beukes et al. (2002) ancl Molris
(2002). For additional information see Lascelles (2002), Morcy (1999), Monis (1987), Powell et
al. (1999), Taylor et al. (2001), Van Schalkwyk and Beukes (1986), and references thelein.
The genesis of tho iron ores within the Cauê Formation in the Quadrilátero Fenífero has
been the subject of clebate since the beginning of the 20th century, ancl contimres to be the focus
of stuclies by several researchers (e.g. Harder and Chamberlin l9l5; Guild 1953; Park 1959; Dorr 1964, 1965; Rarnanaidou 1989; Ramanai<lou et al. 1996; Rosière and Rios 2003). Soft ores
have been expleritred as resiclual concentrations of iron oxicles clue to leaching of contaminatìts

during supergene processes (Dorr 1964; Eichler 1968; Melfi et al. 1976; Viel et al. 1987; Ramanaidou 1989; Ramanaidou et al. 1996). They have also been viewecl as a consequence of
incomplete metasomatism ofthe BIF followed by weathering, as suggested by Don (1965). I{ard
ores have been generally considered to result from the I'eplacement or leaching of gangue
minerals (Dort 1965). The precisc timing ofore formation is also a source of controversy. Dor (1965), for instance, postulated both syn-metamorphic and syn-deformational mineralization.
But there remains clobate ovø the importance of these events (Rosiòre 1981, Rosière aucl Rios
2003).

Unlike other mines in the Quaclrilátero Ferrífero, the Águas Claras mine contains only high-grade ores. These consist of two distinct, main types: soft an<l hard ore. 'I'he sofl ore rep[esents 85% of the overall resource, whefeas the hard ore lepresents only 15o/o. The orebody

dolomitic itabirite deeper down (Fig. 4a). The haril ores generally occut within the soft ores as
minor lens. 'fhese are concotdant to the bedding, although locally they rnay be discorclant ancl
associated with shear zones. The main hard ole occurrences are concentratecl to the wes[ of the
mine, close to the top ofthe sequence. llere they are in contact with qtnrlz itabilite forrning lens
of up to 200 m length along the strike, with thicknesses varying from 5 - 60 r¡ (Fig. 4b). Small concordant lens of hard ore measuring from a few centimeters to nearly a meter thick occur within the clolomitic itabirite at the east sicle of the pit. These lens consist of massive hard ore
formed by almost pure hematite.
The soft ore is characteristically porous ancl very friable. It disaggregates during tlic mining operations and generates a low lump yield. It usually preserves the structure of the itabilite, particularly the meso and microbancling (Fìg.5g), and sometimes exhibits kink-bands
not presenl in the protore.
The harcl ore is dense, compact and generates a high lLrmp yield. Three main subtypes of harcl ore are found at the Águas Claras mine: massive, banded and schistose (Fig. 5h). Massive
hard o¡e has a very low porosity, does not exhibit any kind of structure and commonly shows

exhibits a conspicuous cataclastic foliation. 'Ihis type of hard ore is associated with shear zones

Major differences between the Aguas Claras and Pico mines
Both the Águas Claras and Pico mines are hostecl within the Paleoproteroic itabirites of
the Cauê Formation. Although located in the \¡r'estem and less cleformecl side of the Quadrilátero
Ferrífero, the two mines exhibit clifferent patterns of deformation. At the Águas Claras mine a
penetrative schistosity and a crenulation have developed as a consequence of events that folcled
and thrusted the rocks of the Minâs Supergroup. In the Pico mine the deformation was less

The main lithological cli.lference between the deposits is the presence of clolomitic itabirite in Águas Claras and amphibolitic itabirite in Pico. The genesis of the clolomitic ancl
amphibolic itabirites retnains a source of controversy and cliscussion (Dorr 1965, Veríssimo et al.
2002, Rosière and Rios 2003). For some authors (Veríssimo 1999, Veríssimo et a|.2002), they
represent a sec{imentary facies variation of the Minas sedimcnts. For others (Beukes et al. 2002),
the dolomitic itabirite results from the diagenetic replacement ofchert by calbonate.
The gradual âppearance of quartz within the dolomite bancls, the absence of evidence
indicating replacement of one mineral by the other and the altetnating banding of quartz bands,
dolomite bands and iron oxide bands (Fig. 5e) characterize a grâdual contact between clolomitic
and quartz itabirites at the Águas Claras mine ancl coulcl reprosent a seclimentary facies vatiation.
The same mineral assemblage of quartz-clolomite-iron oxicles founci in a very low-gra<le metamorphic iron-formation of the Sokoman Iron Formation in Canadá was described by Klein
alìd Fink (197 6) as a sedímentary hematite-carbonate facies of the BIF. This could also be the
case in Águas Claras.
At the Pico mine, lens of amphibolitic itabirite occur interlayered with quartz itabirite.
The same occurs at the Alegria mine, in the eastern region of the Quadrilátero Ferrífero (Veríssimo 1999, Veríssimo et al. 2002). Basecl on field relations, petrology ancl geochemistry
ilata, they have interpreted the amphibolitic itabirite and the quartz itabirite as representatives of
the silicate facies and cllert facies respectively. The difficulty in applying the concept of sedimentary facies to iron formations (James 1974) of the Quadrilátero Fetrífero is clue to the
fact that lhe mineral assemblage presently observed may not reflcct the original mineralogical
composition of the sediments of the Minas basin, which have undergone a complex evolution.
No primary minerals are preserved, tlìe textures of the rocks are typically metamorphic and the
new mineral assemblage is strongly oxidized.
Olherwise there is no fielcl eviclence of a regional clesilicification ancl carbonatization of the quartz itabirite as suggestecl by Beukes et al. (2002). Dolomitic itabirite and clolornite of the
Cauê Formation occur along tens of kilometers of the Serra do Cunal presenting gradual contacts. The gradual contact between the Cauê and Gandarela Formations brings an additional
and important difficulty for the idea of carbonatization of the quartz itabirite. The rocks of the
Ganclarela Formation are typically shallow-water carbonate sediments which comprise clolomites

Dolomitic and Quartz itabirites
Mesobanding is the most striking macroscopic characteristic of itabirites at the QF. Mesobanding is defined by altemating millimeter to decimeter hematite rich bands and dolomite/quartz bands (Fig. 6b-d). Microbanding defined by altemating sub-millimeter hematite
and dolomitelquartz laminas are commonly observed within mesobands of itabirites (Fig.9c). In
dolomitic itabirite, the dolomitic bands consist largely of dolomite and up to 40Yo hematite (Fig.
9d). Talc, chlorite and apatite occur as accessory minerals. Thin laminas of apatite parallel to
banding are locally observed (Fig. l0a). Dolomite occurs as euhedral crystals varying from 2 pm
to 15 ¡rm intergrown with hematite and accessory minerals (Fig. l0b). Like the femrginous
dolotnite, microrneter hernatite inclusions form an iron dust within dolomite crystals (Fig. 9a).
Hematite in itabirites occurs as martite þseudomorphs of magnetite after oxidation), tabular
hematite arrd, locally, specularite. Specularite occurs along shear planes, parallel to or truncating
the banding. The hematitic bands are largely comprised of hematite with up to 20%o dolomite and
traces of talc, chlorite and apatite (Fig. l0 c-d). Hematite occurs as dense aggregates of martite
and tabular hematite with individual grains varying from 5 pm to l0 pm. Thicker hematite bands preserve relict magnetite within martite crystals.
Quartz itabirite is macroscopically and texturally similar to dolomitic itabirite, but mesobands rich of quaïlz replace dolomite (Figs. 10e, I la-b). Quartz is generally clean, without
hematite inclusions, and exhibits wavy extinction. Relicts of magnetite are locally observed within martite crystals (Fig. I lc-d). When present, dolomite occurs intergrown with quartz (Fig.
10f). Apatite, chlorite and sericite occur as accessory phases intergrown with quartz and hematite
(Fig. l0 g-h) and, locally, as fine inclusions within quartz (Fig. ll e-Ð.The grain size of all minerals is very frne (5 ¡rm to 25 pm). Quartz bands of the qtrantz itabirite consist of quartz with
varying proportions of hematite (up to 25%) and accessory minerals (i.e., apatite, chlorite and
sericite). Hematite-rich mesobands consist of dense aggregates of hematite with up to l5o/o of quartz.

This group of rocks comprises quafiz itabirite bearing dolomite, cherty dolomite and dolomite that occurs overlying quaftz itabirite at the transition zone to the Gandarela Formation.

Dolomitization and the Genesis of the Dolomitic Itabirite
The distribution of dolomito in the dolomitic itabirite of the Cauê Formation ancl in the
dolomite and marbles of the Gancla¡ela Formation suggest that the original scdiments of these
rocks were largely dolomitized. Although in specific environments, where lhe seawater is hotter

precipitation of dolomite is possible (Tucker and Wright, 1990), it is more probable that the dolomite found in QF results from the dolomítization of earlier carbonates, a common process in
the Proterozoic. According to Tucker and Wright (1990) dolomitization generally appeals to be
an early near-surface phenomenon, where CaCO: minerals precipitated on the seafloor can be
dolomitized by seawater with a high clolomitizing potential. Dolomite is a common mineral
component in BIFs, where it is usually associated with ankerite and calcite (e.g. Arora et al., 1995; Dymek and Klein, 1988; Ewers and Morris, l98l; Floran ancl Papike, 1978; Klein ancl Beukes, 1989). In the Lake Superior region there are unmetamorphosed BIFs corrposed only of dolomite ancl iron minerals (e.g. Klein and Fink, 1916;Perry Jr. et al., 1973). The same occrrs at
the Nabberu basin, westem Australia (Flall and Goode, 1978).
It seems likely that the dolomitic rocks of the Cauê ancl Gandarela Formation result from
clolomitization of earlier carbonates during the diagenesis. Beukes et al. (2002), howevcr, consider the dolomitlc itabirite as tho result of the desilisification and carbotiatization of quartz
itabirite through a hyclrothermal process, without presenting any evidence for this process. There
is no field evidence to support this paragenetic sequence. On the contrary, the coexistence of quartz and<lolomitic itabirite is locally observed in drill cores ancl outcrops of the Águas Claras
Mine sometimes forming a triply bancted rock (Fig. 6c). Quartz and dolomite are commonly

reaction or hyclrother mal substitution (Fig. 8d).

Curral, along c. ll0 Km of extcnsion, indrcating a regional dislribution for these rocks, It is likely that a regional hydrothermal process of clolomitizatiorì ofthe quartz itabirite, as suggested
by Beukes et aI. (2002), would leave some indication of its occunence, which was not observed

carbonate sediments modified by a clolomitization process which occurred cluring diagencsis,

Minas Supergroup indicate that marine transgression-rogression cycles acted during the cleposition of the Minas basin.
Deposition of BIFs cluting marine transgrcssions is suggested for BIFs of the I-Iamersley
basin and the Transvaal basin (Klein and Beukes, 1989; Simonson, 1996; Simonson et al., 1993), both contemporâneous with the Minas basin (Babinski et al-, 1995a). CONCLUSIONS
Dolomitic ancl quartz itabirite are metamorphosed oxide 1àcies BfFs of thc Lake Superior type of Paleoproterozoic agc, contcmporancous to the giant BlFs olthc l.Iamersley and Transvaal basins. They consist of altemated millirnetric to decimctric bands of dolomite-rich and
hematite-rich, and cluartz-rich and hematite-rich, respectively. Both rocks have a very simple
chemical composition, with Fc2Or, CaO, MgO and LOi reprcsenting morc than 98% of the average composition of dolomitic itabirite and FezO¡ ancl SiO2 constituting more than 98% of the
average composition of quartz itabirite. Itabirites were highly oxidized and pr.esent Fe3*/(Fe2*+Fe3n) ratios highel than 0.98, much greater than the average ratio of othe¡ Paleoproterozoic BIFs.
Trace elements colìcentrations in itabirites are very low and range from <l0 pprn (Y, Sc, Be, Cu, Ga, Ge, Rb, Nb, Mo, Ag, In, Sn, Cs, FIf, Tl, Pb, Bi, As, Cd, Th, U, Sb) ro
concentrations between 10 and 55 ppm (Ba, Sr, Zr, V, Ni, Zn, Co, Cr and IREE). Dolomitic and
quartz itabirite do not present major dif'l'erences in tmce element contents.
The FIREE enrichment pattem exhibited by both itabirites shows a modern seawater REE
signature overprinted by a hydrothemal pattem represented by positive EupAAS anomalies. A
marine sedimentary origin of the sediments of the dolomitic itabirite is reinforced by its REE
signatue, by the C and O isotopic composition, typical of marine carbonates, and by its Y/l,Io
ratios very similar to that of seawater. A strong coffelation between Alz0: and TiO2 (r>0.9) indicates a minor terrigenous componcnt f'or the chemically precipitated, marine sediments of the
Cauê Formation.
The differences on the REE signatures ofthe itabirites suggest that they preoipitated from
aqueous solutions of different compositions, with the dolomitio itabirite receiving higher contribution of marine surface waters laiden continental sediments and quartz itabirite of marine
bottom watels. Sea-level fluctuations caused by marine transgression-regressions are responsible
for changes in the aqueous solution composition. These changes ar.e expressed by dolomitic-, quartz- and amphibolitic itabirites, which replesent lateral ancl vertical facies transitions of carbonatic, cherty and shaly BIFs respectively.

INTRODUCTION
The Aguas Claras iron-ore rnine is located in the Quaclrilátero Ferrífero (QF), Southeastem Region of Brazil, state of Minas Gerais (Fig- l). Open-pit mining a[ Águas Claras
commenced in 1973 and, by 2002, when thc mine .¡/as closecl, approximately 288 Mt of high- grade iron ore (average Fe>68%) had been mined on the crest and along the slopes of a segment

Despite its world-class category and the significant amount of data gatherecl on the mine
since mining began in 1973, very little geological information on the mine is available in publishecl literature (Gomes 1986; Viel et al. 1987; Flackspacher 1979). Recently, Spier et al.
(2003) clescribed the geology ofthe Águas Claras ancì Pico iron mines ancl presented data for the
main chemical constituents of the iron ore at those mines. This study complements that previous

Itabirites of the Cauô Formation arc vely similar in lithology to most major oxide-facies BIFs

Unlike other mines of the QF, the Águas Claras mine containeci rnainly high-gracle ore (Fe

The iron-rich bands contain hernatite (>80%), interstitial carbonates and pores (Fig. ae-f).
The average hematite grain size is similar to that of the dolomitic bands (- 20 prm) ranging from
5-30 pm. Hematite occurs mainly as tabular and granular crystals growirrg over martite (hematite
pseudomorphous after magnetite), forming a dense network. Hematite also occurs locally as
specularite. Traces of magnetite are observed in the nuclei of some hematite crystals, especially
in the coarser iron-rich bands.
Accessory minerals are also present irr the dolomitic itabirite. Talc occurs intergrown
with dolomite (Fig. 49) and associated with chlo¡ite in thin veins. Apatite can be found forming
monomineral layers (<l mrn) or as isolated euhedral crystals (4-10 pm) intergrown with or included in hematite and dolomite crystals (Fig. ah). Chlorite occurs along veins and shear planes.
The lron Ore
The Águas Claras orebody comprises soft and hard high-grade ores (Fig. 3b-c). The
orebody is a bedding-concordant, 2,500 m long, roughly tabular-shaped lens with a maximum
thickness of 300 m and formed essentially by soft ores (Fig. 2b). The hard ores generally occur
within the soft ores as minor lenses concordant to the bedding. The depth of the orebody is variable, extending to over 400 rn below the surface at the center of the pit bottom and then grading into the parental fresh dolomitic itabirite deeper down (Fig. 2a).In this contact region, it
is very common to find the presence of pinnacles of fresh dolomitic itabirite surrounded by the
soft ore (Fig. 3d). Higher levels of contaminants in the iron ore, especially apatite, occur in this
zone. Dip and strike of the orebody are conformable with regional trends, i.e., strike is northeast-
southwest, dip is 65" to 80' SE.
The soft ore is gray, friable and has a laminated appearance. It preserues partially the original structure of the protore, particularly meso- and microbanding, which is characterizedby
the presence of massive and porous bands within the ore, parallel to the banding of the itabirite
(Figs. 3b, 5a-f). Adjacent bands are rarely of similar thickness. Field relationships show that iron-rich bands of dolomitic itabirite grade into the massive bands in the iron ore, while dolomite-rich bands grade into the porous bands. Even massive bands are porous, but they have
less than 30 percent of pore space, and individual pores are isolated in massive hematite. Generally massive bands are broken and disrupted while porous bands show free aggregates of hematite between pores (Fig. 5f-g). Kink-bands (not present in the protore) are locally observed.

Petrographic and SEM observations of the massive, bandecl ancl schistose hard iron ores
have shown a very simple mineralogical composition. The iron oxide rnineralogy is the same of
l.he soft ole. Gangue minerals are very rare, consisting of clolomite and, locally, apatite and talc.
In weathered liard ores gangue minerals are generally absent, creating a macropolosity. ln highly
fi'acturecl oreboclies, goethite and kaolinite occLu as thin fihns on the surface of the ore, oven at
deeper depths (Fig. 3!. There is no difference itr the mineralogical composition of the three major sub-types ofhard ore, except in fabric ancl porosity.
Massive halcl ore consists of tabular and granular hematite (up to 80%) ranging in sizc
from 5 to 30 prn (average of20 pm), forming a granoblastic fabrio (Figs. l6a-d). Martite (up to
50 pm) with remnants of magnetite occur between her¡atite crystals (Fig. l6e). Locally, it is
possible to observe the growth of hematite over rnartite crystals. Porosity in hard massive ores
mày vàry from approximately 5 to 20o/o, and pore size from <I to 50 Frm. Fresh ores exhibit the
lowest porosity of all hard ores, around 3ol0, increasing up to 20%o in weathered samples.
Banded h¿rcl ore consists of altemated massive and porous layers (Fig. 16fl. Tabular and
granular hematite are the main iron oxicles (up to 70%) with grain size ranging florn 5 - 20 pm
(Fig. 169). They grow over martite or occur as isolated crystals. Martite with remnants of
magnetite may occur as indiviclual crystals ranging from 30 - 50 ¡Lrn or forming clense aggregates, representing up to 5% of the volume. Speculalite (up to 5%) occurs locally, aloÌìg
shear planes parallel to or cutting the banding ancl defining a cliscontinuously developed foliaiion. Porosity is highly variable in bancled iron ores, reaching up to 30% of the volume.
Schistose hard ore prescnts a lepidoblastic fabric which is composecl mainly of tabular
hematite and specularite (up to 70%) wrapping around porphyroclastic agglegates of tabular ancl
granular hematite (up [o 50%, Fig. l6h). Porosity in the schistose ore ranges from 5 to 20%.

DISCUSSION
Comparison between hard and soft ores
The major difference between hard ancl soft ores, besicles the mechanical strength, is their
mode of occurrence. The soft ore forms a large, km-sized lens, which grades laterally and
vertically to the parent clolomitic itabirite. Fielcl relationships show the transition from the
dolomite-rich bands of the dolomitic itabirite into the porons band ofthe soft ore. This transition
is marked by dissolution of the dolomite-rich bancls, thereby producing a highly porous residue
which is very rich in the hematite originally present within the clolornite-rich banrls. The i¡on-
rich bands of the clolomitic ifabilite are little affectecl by this dissolution process and forrn the
massive band of the soft ore. The hard ore occrrs as discontinuous lenses within the fiesh
clolomitic itabirite ancl sofl ore. These fielcl relationships indicate that the hard iron ore was
formed earlier than the soft iron ore. lt also suggests rhat the harcl iron ore, like the iron-rich bands of the dolomitic itabirite, was little affectecl by the dissolution plocess, remaining as lenses
within the soft ore.
The next important clifference betwcen harcl ancl soft ores is potosity, which control their
mechanical strength. Two types of porosity are observecl in the iron ores: macro and microporosity. The former is related to the spaces between the iron oxides crystals and constitutes the major factor affccting the hardness of ths ol'e. It is formed by leaching of the gangue minerals, probably by weathering solutions (see text below). The latter is relatecl to the
presence of pores within the iron oxide crystals which are fonnecl<luring the oxiclation of
201
magnetite into martite. The hard iron ore is much less porous than the soft ore, which accounts
for its harclness. The soft ores are highly porous and, consequently, soft. A more frequent prosence of carbonate in tl,e rock plior to dissolution results in higher polosity ancl higher
friability. Variations in the porosity and fabric of the harcl ore ale responsible fbr the different:
sub-types observed,
'Ihe major difference in the mineralogy of the hard and soft ores is the slightly higher
amount of gangue minerals in the latter. The gangue minerals are also different in each type of
ore. Although both ores have a very low amount ofdehimental impurities, these are concentrated

Formation of Tabular and Granular Hematite Within Martite Crystals
Even though the question of which primary iron minerals precipitatecl on the sea floor
during the growth of the BIFs remains a source of debate in literature, there is a general consensus that they were mostly ferric (hydr)oxides (goethite and/or hematite) (Ohmoto 2003;
Trendall 2002). A later process during diagenesis and/or metamorphism transformed the feric
(hydr)oxides into magnetite (Monis 1993; Perry Jr. et aL 1973; Walker 1984; Walker 1987).
Magnetite is found ubiquitously in BIFs throughout the world- In the QF region, it is intelpreted
to be the oldest iron oxide of the iron mineral assemblage (Rosière l98l; Rosière ancl Chemale Jr. 2000; Rosière et al. 1993; Rosière ancl Rios 2004). The coarse crystals of magnetite in BIFs of
the QF sr.rggest that they were folmed during diagenesis and/or metamorphism, considering that
primary iron precipitates must have been coloidal.
Magnetite was almost totally oxidized and recrystallized during the metamorphic and
tectonic evolution of the BIFs of the Cauê Formation (Rosière l98l). The transition from magnetite to martite is less well preserved in the Águas Clalas rocks, but it is well docurnented
in other sites in the QF. The most impressive fèature observecl in this study is the development of
hematite within mattite crystals, 'Ihe petrographìcal analyses indicate that recrystallization of
martite during metamoryhism and deformation (probably during the Transamazonian Orogenesis) was responsible for the generation ofthe hematite crystals within martite, accorcling
to the mechanisms proposed by llackspacher et al. (2001), Lagoeiro (1998), Rosière (1981) and
Rosière et al. (2001). The degree of recrystallization, ho.rr'ever, was not uniform, making it possible to observe the several steps of transformation fiom ma1tite to tabular hematite, passing

Hematite II of Rosière and Rios (2004) and are conspicuously observed in our samples. The passage from martite to tabular hematite in Águas Claras is an intermediate step in the development of specularite, which occurs in high strained zones of the QF, according to Rosière

Ore Gencsis
Most of the iron ore proclucecl in the world results from the enrichment of precambrian
BIFs, but the processes responsible for this enrichment are still unclear and constitute a souroe of
debates in the literature (Dalstra et al. 2002; Kneeshaw and Keped 2002; Moris 2002a-c). Two
end-member genetic rnoclels have been proposed: supergene velsus hydrothermal enrìchment of
a BIF protore. Supergene iron ores are the most abundant type of iron ores either in the QF, where tlrey represent rnore than 70n/o of nhe 27 Gt of geological tesources (Gomes, 1986; MBR
and CVRD, internal reports), or in the Westem Australian Hamersley basin, where the martite-
goethite ores account for some 90% or more ofthe BlF-derivecl enrichment ores (Harmsworth et
a1., 1990; Monis, 2002c). Supergene ore arises by the selective leaching of gangue minerals
from the BIF by ground water and the residual accumulation of the iron oxicles. Hypogene ores
form the richest iron orebodies. Their genesis is ascribed to the interaction of the BlFs with a
hydrothermal fluid, which dissolved chert (quartz), leaving porcs spaces, that were or not filled
by a new generation of iron oxides.
The oocurrence of the har<l, massive high-gracle ores within lì'esh itabirite at the Águas
Claras and Tamancluá mines is a sh'ong eviclence of their hypogene origin. This type of ore is
similar to those described, for instance, by Taylol et al. (2001), Beukes et al. (2002) and Guedes
et al. (2002), .,vhich are interpreted as formed by hyclrothermal fluids. However, at Águas
Claras, petrographic and mineralogic data provide little information regarding the hypogene
solutions and their precipitates. Flematite has a very simple chemical composition and a wide
stability field, thereby restricting its use in metallogenetic stuclies. Additional difficulties, such as
superimpositiotr of tectonic events and weathcring, turn the undol'stancling of thc genesis of this

hard ore into a difficr.rlt pr.rzzle. Nevertheless, there are some new insights into this subject. They
atose from the infrared microscopic analysis and t'luicl inclusion studies in hematite carriecl out
by Rosière and Rios (2004). These authors suggest that the lormation of the hald massive hrgh-
grade oreboclies occulrecl during the Transamazonian evont (ca. 2.1-2.0 Ga; Alkmim ancl
Marshak, 1998) and developed in two stages. ht the first, contractional stage of the Transamazonian orogeny a pewasive magnetite mineralization occurred in the BIF by reduced
motamorphic fluicls- Hematite mineralization occuüed during the collapse stage of the orogeny,
coincident with lhe uplift of the basement, intrusion of granitic plntons and extension of the
crust, and involved low-temperature meteoric fluids moving clownwards from the surface along
normal faults and fractures. These flr¡ids wele also responsible for the oxiclation of magnetite
(martitization), and were concentrated only at sites of great permeability such as folcl hinges,
forming the hard, massive high-grade orebodies.
Hârdel to explain is the origin of the giant, soft high-grade oreboclies, such as the Águas
Claras orebocly. Tlle general lack of typical secondary minerals as goethite in the ore coulcl
indicate leaching of gangue minerals from BIFs by hypogene solutions, but in some cases, other

The soft ore al the QF orebodies is generally interlayered with or surounding the hard,
massive, hypogene ores. This relation led many authors (Beukes et a|.2002; Dorr II 1965; Guild 1953; Rosière and Rios 2004) to propose its hypogene-supergene modified origin. llypogene-
supergene modified models comprise an initial, hypogene stage, with either leaching of all the
chert from the BIF protore leaving pore spaces (Dorr iI 1965; Guilct 1953) or with metasomatic replacement of those minerals by carbonates, followcd by a snpergene stage that leached the
hytlrotermal minerals formed in the previous stage (Beukes el al.2002). Águas Claras mine was
mentioned by Beukes et al. (2002) as the best example, one where the dolomitic itabirite "obviously developed from the replacement of chert bands in iron-formation". Flypogene- supsrgene modified genetic models were also proposecl for the genesis of the high-grade lrematite ores at the flamersley ancl Carajás Provinces (Beukes et al. 2002; Guedes et al.2002;
Taylor et al. 2001; Thorne et al. 2004; Webb et al. 2004). Recently, Dalstra and Guedes (2004)
suggested that magnetite-carbonate-amphibole, mâgnetite-carbonate or hematite-carbonate ptecursors were essential in the formation of high-grade hematite ores worldwicle. Their proposed genetic model involves early hyclrothermal depletion ofsilica in the host iron formation
and introduction of Ca-Fe-Mg-carbonates, followed by supergene leaching of the carbonates,
long after they ale formed, to create the high-glade hematite ores.

CONCLUSIONS
The detailed minel'alogical and geoûhemical study of the soft and hard high-gracle ores rn
the Águas Claras nine showed â very simple mineralogical and chemical composition. Both ores
consist essentially of hematite, occuuing as martite, anhedral to glanula/tabular hcmatite and,
locally specularite- Hematite is very pure ancl well crystallizecl. It occurs growing over martite
crystals or as individual crystals. Gangue minerals are vely rare, corlsisting of dolomite, sericite,
chlorite and apatite in the hard and soft ores, and Mn-oxicìes and fenihyclrite in the soft ore,
where they ale concentrated within the porous bands. Flard and soft oles consist almost ontirely
of Fe2O3, with higher amount of detrimental impurilies, especially MnO, in the soft ore. Botl.r
hard and soft ores are very low in h'ace elements. The soft ore preserves the REEY pattem of the
dolomitic itabirite, suggesting that weathering promoted a residual enrichment in REEY, without
fractionation.
Field relationships, petrological and geochemical data indicate that the high-grade ores at
the Águas Claras mine have a clual origin, involving hypogene and supergene processes. The
occurrence of the hard massive high-grade ore within fresh dolomitic itabirite is a good evidence
of its hypogene origin. Microstructures and granoblastic fabric of the harcl ore inclicate that its
genesis occurrecl prior to or concomitant with the main cleformational event that affected the
tocks at the \ryestern side of the QF, tìuring the Transamazonian orogeny (2.1-2.0 Ga). Mineralogical and geochemical data provided little inforrnatiou tegarcling lhe hypogene solutions
ancl their precipitates at the Águas Claras mine. Further investigations on the detailecl stnrctural
contlol of the hard high-grade orebodies, oombinecl with rnicrothermometio investigations, are
necessary to determine the lole of hyclrothennal fluids in the folmation of the haral high-grade
ores at the QF.
Otherwise, despite the arguments about the origin of the clolomitic itablrite, the fielcl
relationships, mineralogical and geochemical clata strongly indicate the supergene origin of the
soft high-grade ore of the Águas Claras mine. Weathering of the dolomitic itabirite leachecl
dolomite, leaving a highly porous, saprolitic ole, consisting almost entirely of hematite with very
suborclinated gangue minerals. Among these are Mn-oxides antl ferrihyclrite, precipitated along

pores and fractures planes of the ore from solutions carrying Mnz* and Fe2' liberated cluring
dolomite clissolution. The occurrence of feruidydrite in the soft ore is a good evidence of its
supergenÇ origin. Dala from palynological studies caried out in secliments ofbasius that blanket
sorne high-gracle cleposits in the QF, associatecl with 40Ar/reAr

hostecl within the soft iron ore of the Sapecatlo mine, suggest that most of the soft ore in the QF
was formed during a major, intense, chemical weatheritrg period, around 5l-41 Ma.
The original composition of fhe itabiritic protore has a major role in the genesis of high-
ancl low-gracle sofì ores in the QF. Under the same weathering antl structural conditions, the
clolomitic itabirite is more favorable to form high-gracle deposits than quartz itabirite, due to the
higher solubility of dolomite in relation to quLairtz. Field relationships at the Águas Claras and
Capão Xavier deposits suggest that it is not possible to form huge sof't high-grade cleposits from
quârtz itabitite, rurless another control, such as impermeable baniers, hacl played an important
role.
The occumence of huge tonnage of soft ore hostecl in quartz itabirite in the Tamadrlá
deposit, and the close association between haril, medium and soft ores, suggest that all those ores
were mostly formed cluring the hypogene process that generated the harcl ore, representing
different stages of the hypogene alteration. If this hypothesis is correct, the prcsence of a carbonate-rich protore is not a necessary condition to the genesis of large high-grade oreboclies,
as sirggested by Beukes et al. (2002) ancl by Dalstra ancl Guedes (2004).
Though rnany issues remain to be clarified, we believe that the hypogene-supergene

Weathering profiles overlying the Sapecaclo, Pico ancl Andaime iron ore deposits,
Quadrilátero Ferrífero (QF), Minas Gerais, Brazil, reach depths of 150-400 m ancl host worlcl-
class supergene iron oreboclies. In adclition to hematite, goethite, ancl some relic quartz, the
deeply weathered itabirites (metamorphosecl banded iron formation) contain supergene cllptomelane, hollandite, ancl pyrolusite. These manganese oxicles are preferentially concenûated at the contact between weathered Cauô Formation itabirites and adjacent dolomites
of the Gandarela Formation, and their clistribution provirlcs information on the propagation of the
weathering front as the supergene ore boclies formed.
Laser incremental-heating ooAr/toA. results for 69 grains extractecl fiom 23 samples
collected at depths ranging from 5 to 150 m reveal ages ranging fromca.62 to 14 Ma. Older Mn-
oxides occur near the surface, while younger Mn-oxides occur at depth. However, many
samples collected at the weathering-bedrock interface yield ages in the 5l-41 Ma range, suggesting that the weathering profiles in the Quadrilátero Feffífero had already reached their
present depth in the Paleogene. The age velsus depth clistribution obtained in this study suggests
that little further advance of the weathering front has occurred in the Quadrilátero Fenífero
lateritic profiles during the Neogene.

GEOT,OGICAL SETTfNG
Regional Geology
The geology and the lithoshatigraphy of the QF were described in detail by the USGS-
DNPM team between 1946 ancl 1963, ancl snmmarizecl by Doru II (1969)- Since then, the subject
has been reviewed by several authors (Alkmim and Marshak, 1998; Chemale Jr. et al., 1994;
Ladeira and Viveiros, 1984; Marshak and Alkmim, 1989; Renger et al., 1994). The most important lithostlatigraphic units of the Quaclrilátero F'errífero (Fig. l) are Archean to Paleoproterozoic granitic-gneissic basemcnt, Archean greenstone belt sequences (Rio clas Velhas
Supergroup), the Paleoproterozoic Minas Supetgroup and post-Minas intrusive rocks.
The giant iron ore deposits of the Quaclrilátero Ferrífero are hosted in itabirites of the
Minas Supergroup, which consist of three Paleoproterozoic sequences (Babinski et al., 'l995; Nocc, 1995; Renger et al., 1994). The lowest unit is the Calaça Group, which consists of alluvial
conglomerates and sanclstones grading upwards into shallow-water marine siltstones ancl
mudstones, The intermecliate ltabira Group consists mainly of chemical sedimentary rocks. A
metamorphosed bandecl iron formation (itabirite) unit of variable composition occurs at the base

Geomorphologically, the Quadlilátero Ferrífero (literally the iron quadrangle) consists of
a ronghly square 7000 km2 tegion (Fig. 2a) characterized by variotts plateaus, ranging in height
from 1100 to 2100 m elevation, sur¡ounded by dissected plains at ca. 500-600 m elevation. The
quadrangle is delimited by steeply dipping BIFs ancl quartzites that constitute elevated ancl
highly resistant barriers to erosion ancl scarp retr€at driven by the creeks ancl streams dtaining
into the plateau. The western limit of the QF is the Serra da Moecla, its northern limit the Ser¡a
do Cuffal, the eastcl'n limit the Serra do Caraça, ancl the southern limit the Sena clo Ouro Branco
(Figs. I and 2). The oore of the Quadrangle is drained by the north-flowing Rio cìas Velhas, creating a tlissectecl winclow into the Archean Bação Complex (Fig. 2a). This inner depression is
surrouncled by several tleeply weathered plateaus developed on BlFs ancl quartzites. The eastern
section of the QF hosts a 700 km2 plateau, the Moeda Syncline, clelimited by the Serras da
Moeda (W), Sena do Curral (N), Serra clas Serrinhas (E), and Serra do Otro Branco (S) (Fig.
2a). This plateau hosts several important supergene ore boclies, included the Sapecado and
Andaime deposits, located in the Sena das Serrinhas, investigatetl in this study (Fig.2b).
Weathering profilcs along the Sema da Moeda were investigated in an associated study (Cauno
and Vasconcelos, 2003).
The QF plateaus have been interpreted as remnants of an ancient erosion surface
developed before the Africa-South America break-up (the Gondwana Surface of King (1956)).
Weathering profìles on the plateaus are consistently deeper (up to 400 m) and more<leveloped
than weathering profiles on sunounding plains and dissected valleys (<100 m). Landsurfaces on
the plateaus are also distinct fi'om the surrouncling plains because they are blanketed by strongly
iron-hydroxicle cemented covers (cangas), whioh impart a smooth chatacter to the plateau
lanclsurfaces. When the cangas are breached by recent erosion, they form shatp scatps (Fig. 2c),
another distinctive characteristic of this landscape. F'inally, internal basins on the plateaus (e.g.,
Bacias do Fonseca and Gandarela), fillecl with argillite, lignite, sandstone, diamictite, and
kaolinitic sediments now partially weatherecl to bauxite, are associatecl with collapse structures
(karstic lakes) formed during weathering of unclerlying banded iron formations (Ribeiro, 2003)
or with extensional tectonic activity during the Paleogene (Maizatto, 2001; SantAnna et al.,
1997). We chose to study the weathering history of two supergene iron ore deposits in the

Manganese Oxide Paragen€sis
Fielcl ancl petrographic observations indicate that Mn-oxides samplecl in [his shrdy formed
cluring chemical weathering of the dolomite-bearing itabirite of the Cauê Formation ancl tho
clolomite of the Gandarcla Folmation. Manganese and iron are present as minor elements iri the
clolomite. Manganese ancl iron are also common in carbonate celnents associatecl with the
diagenetic or hyclrothermal alteration ofthe BIFs. Mn'2 ancl Fe'2 are released into the weathering
solutions during the dissolution of the Mn-bearing carbonates. As long as the \¡r'eather¡ng solutions remain relatively reducing ancl neutral to acidic, Mn'2 stays in solution. If the Mn*2-
bearing solutions encourter clescending oxygenatecl mcteoric solutions along permeable horizons
and fault planes, Mn*2 readily oxidizes and precipitates as Mn*a-oxides ancl -hydroxicles
(pyrolusite, ramsclellite, manganite). Alternatively, when Mn*2-bearing weathering solutions
oncourÌter str-ongly alkaline conditions, which often occurs at the contact between the BIF and
the host carbonates of the Gandarela Formation, Mnt2 may also reaclily oxiclize and precipitate as
Mn*a oxides/hyclroxides. If, in addition to Mnu2, the weathering solutions also contain clissolved
K*1, Ba*2, or other cations, complex tunnel structure manganese oxides (romanéchile, hollandite,
cryptomelane, todorokite) may form. The processes above account for the common occurrence
of Mn-oxicles along faults and along the contact between the BIF and the adjacent carbonate
rocks. Manganese oxide paragenesis in the supergene iron orebodies suggests an intimate association of the oxides with the weathering of the banded iron formations. This, in tu¡n, âssures that geochronological analyses of the Mn-oxides provrcle information on the weathering
history of the BIFs.

Paleoclimatic Implications
The distribution of lateritic weathering profiles lTas been usecl as a paleoclimatic indicator
(Crowley ancl North, l99l; Fmkes, 1979; Nahon, 1986). The authols consider the presence of those profiles as indicative of warm temperatures with seasonal rains, favoring intense chemical
weathering ancl consequently the development ofcleep weathering profiles.
A major limitation in using weathering profrles as paleoclimatic inclicator is the absence
of reliable numerical ages. In addition, the few studies whele ages of profiles are reportecl
(Dammer et dl., 1996; Dammer et al., 1999; Ruffet et al., 1996a; Vasconcelos et al., 1994b)
suggest that latetitic profiles do not form instantly but record a protl'acted history of mineral
dissolution and reprecipitation lasting tens of millions of years. The present study confirms that
lateritic ptofiles reflect a protracted history of exposure. The ages of the minerals in the profiles
record times in the past more propitious to chemical weathering.
The majority of the supergene Mn-oxides samples analyzed precipìtated between 5l ancl 4l Ma, sr.rggesting hot and wet climatic conclitions at that time interval. Palynologic clata for the
Gandarela and Fonscca basins reveals the plesence of an exubelant ancl diversifiecl paleoflora in
the Eocene, indicative ofhot and wet envitonmental conditions (Maizatto, 2001). This period is
coincitlent with the major periocls of chemical weatherrng tegistered at the Carajás, Amazon
region, Brazil (Ruffet et al., 1996a; Vasconcelos et al., 1994b), in Australia (Dammer et al.,
1996; Dammer et a1., 1999) and in Burkina Faso, Africa (Hénocque et al., 1998b). This might
indicâte that the climatic conditions that favoretì intense chemical weathering in the Eocene had
a mote global character.
Landscape Evolution Implications
The deeply strati{ied weathering profiles in the Quarìrilátero Ferrífero record weathering
processes alreacly orrgoing at the Paleogene, and may suggest even more ancient weathering in
the region. The absence of deeply stratified weathering profiles in the adjacent dissected valleys
(Fig. 2a), and evidence suggesting that weathering profiles in these dissectecl parts of the
landscape are much younger than the pro{iles on the plateaus (Carmo and Vasconcelos, 2004)
corroborate previous suggestions that the landsurfaces blanketing the QF plateaus are much olcler
than the acljacent disscctcd landsudaces. The lanclsurface characterized by the QF plateaus have

Implications for the Supergene Enrichment of Banded Iron Formations
The geochlonological results in this stucþ petmit drawing three major conclusions:
. that the supergene enrichment blankefs that make the Quadrilátero Ferrífero such a prolifìc iron-proclucing region were already forming at more than 60 Ma;
. that most of the supergene processes had already reachecl their present extent at ca. 40 Ma;
. ancl that weathering processes in the Neogene have contributed little to the fufther advance of the weathering fronts in the supelgene orebodies.
In addition, we may safely conclude that giant supergene iron oreboclies are likely to be
found only in the high elevation plateaus (Gondwana Suface) that were exposecl to the more
intense ancl prolonged weathering history. Dissected plains and valleys surrounding the QF
plateaus are likely to host only incipient supergene blankets.
The fact lhat the supergene enrichment blankets likely reached their present depths at ca.
40 Ma suggest that weathering solutions percolating through the profile were ineffective at
promoting fuÍher advances of the weathering front once the profile reachecl a certain depth.
This diminished weathering capacity may be relate<l to diminishing leactivity of the weathering
solutions at depth (e.g., depletion in dissolved oxygen or saturation with dissolved species), or it
may reflect the horizontal, as opposed to the vertical, rnigration of the weathering solutions once
they reach certain depths. The horizontally migrating weathering solutions dewater at the sicles
of the cliffs (Serra cla Setrinha, Figs. I and 2) at the headwaters of local springs.
CONCLUSIONS
Deep weathering profiles developecl within Paleoptotet ozoic BIFs of the Cauô Folrnation
at the Quaclrilátero Ferrífeto host Mn-oxides suitable for ooAr/toAr
clating. These Mn-oxicles are
concentratecl in supergene Fe-Mn ore ancl manganifelous itabirite at the contact with the
Gandarela Formation. They consist of minerals of the hollandite group (cryptomelane and
hollandite) antl pyrolusite formed by precipitation from complex (Mn-, Fe-, K-, ancl Ba-rich)
weathering solutions. Petrographic and SEM investigations reveal the presence of several generations of Mn-oxit1es.
Laser-heating 'oAloAr data reveal ages ranging from 62 [o 14 Ma, inclicating a prolongecl history of weathering at the Quadtilátero Ferrífeto, already ongoing at least in
Paleogene and continuecl until Neogene. The rnajority of Mn-oxides, however, precipitatecì from
51 - 4l Ma with a peak at 47 Ma. This period is coinciclent with lhe development of srnall basins formed by the collapse of the underlying BIFs cluring intonse chemical weathering, as inclicatecl
by palynologic clata obtained in the sediments.
Samples collected near the present surface or near the contact with the weathering-
bedrock interface present similat ages, indicating that the main weathering process was
developed around 46 Ma ago. Further chemical weathering had limitecl effect on the weathering
of the BIFs, which means that giant supergene iron ore cleposits were completely formed at the
Paleogene.
The coinciclence of the major period of precipitation of the Mn-oxicles (and therefore of
intense chemical weathering) at the QF with major periocls of precipitation in the Brazilian
Amazon (Ruffet et al., 1996a; Vasconcelos et al., 1994b), Australia (Dammer et al., 1996;
Dammer et al., 1999) and westetn Aûica (Héuocque et al., 1998a; flénocque et al., 1998b)
suggests that climatic conditions which favored intense chernical weathering in the Eocene hacl a
more global character.
